Award.AwardTitle: Thermodynamic Formalism and Dynamical Systems Arising from Geometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
The key aims of this research are to further develop the theory of thermodynamic formalism and to apply powerful techniques from ergodic theory and dynamical systems to examples of special geometric interest. Thermodynamic formalism is a powerful and versatile tool in the study of the global statistical properties of dynamical systems, originally motivated by ideas from statistical mechanics. Key goals of the project are (1) to study the evolution of dynamical invariants of negatively curved manifolds under Ricci flow, (2) to develop thermodynamic techniques to study the beta-transformation and related maps, (3) to develop thermodynamic formalism for the Teichmueller flow.

Since the 1930?s, a key motivation in the development of the ergodic theory of dynamical systems has been the study of problems in geometry. This project belongs to that rich tradition, and covers a selection of problems where state of the art techniques will produce new results at the intersection of dynamical systems and geometry. The investigation of the effect of Ricci flow on dynamical invariants of negative curvature manifolds combines the powerful techniques of smooth dynamical systems with state of the art innovations from the Ricci flow literature. The beta-transformation, which has been studied extensively since 1957, arises naturally in number theory. New results are now possible due to a recent breakthrough co-authored by the Principal Investigator. Teichmueller theory is an area of intensive current research at the intersection of geometry, topology, number theory and dynamics. There is great scope for the development of thermodynamic formalism for systems arising in this context, and the results will be useful for a variety of geometric and statistical applications. The project will both advance the theory of dynamical systems and build connections between different branches of mathematics (dynamics, PDE, number theory, Teichmueller theory). The focus of this research is on deriving fundamental pure results, so there is significant potential that the tools developed here will yield future applications in dynamics, geometry and beyond. In addition, the project has a number of educational benefits. The Principle Investigator will (1) disseminate the research through publications and talks, (2) integrate research with teaching by delivering mini-courses and seminars for graduate students and advanced undergraduates, (3) work with Penn State Outreach to promote learning and participation at the K-12 level, with particular emphasis on underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The outcomes of this project constitute a major development in the area of thermodynamic formalism, which is a well established subfield of ergodic theory and dynamical systems. Thermodynamic formalism was pioneered in the 1970's by such luminaries as Sinai, Ruelle and Bowen, and has remained an active research area ever since. The theory originated from the ideas and intuition of statistical mechanics, and is a powerful tool to understand the orbit structure and global statistical properties of dynamical systems. Results on uniqueness of equilibrium states are one of the key tools in thermodynamic formalism, and often yield many further applications, including large deviations principles and results on multifractal analysis. The work developed in this project is the first fundamentally new approach to be introduced to the field since the development of the countable state shift theory in the 90's through influential work of Sarig and others. 

This approach has allowed us to establish the theory of unique equilibrium states in higher dimensional smooth settings that were previously completely intractable. Our recent preprint concerning the diffeomorphisms of Mane and Bonatti-Viana exemplifies the benefit of our approach, and demonstrates a major advance in this subfield of dynamical systems.  The impact of this project will continue to increase as our approach yields fruit in other settings of special interest such as the geodesic flow in non-positive curvature.

Specific outcomes include:

a) Six papers/preprints on thermodynamic formalism, which constitute a novel and fruitful approach to the area. This program of work consists of both general machinery that can be applied in the future, and also applications to dynamical systems of special interest such as beta-transformations and certain model higher dimensional systems beyond uniform hyperbolicity.

b) One of the preprints mentioned above applies these thermodynamic tools to the setting of certain maps with partial hyperbolicity or dominated splittings on the 3-torus and 4-torus (namely, the Mane and Bonatti-Viana families of maps). This is an area of great interest in the smooth dynamics community, and was intractable using previous techniques. These are essentially the first results on uniqueness of equilibrium states in a partially hyperbolic setting, and as such can be expected to have significant impact.

c) The PI wrote a paper which adapts ideas from thermodynamic formalism to bioinformatics, which has been published in the Journal of Mathematical Biology. This research direction was initially unexpected, but fits well with the philosophy of the project, which is to apply and develop thermodynamic formalism in areas of special interest. 

In addition to the impact on the principle discipline of the project (ergodic theory and dynamical systems), the project also makes a significant contribution to genomic biology, by adapting ideas from thermodynamic formalism to that setting.  Our approach fits well the the 'big data' philosophy, as our framework gives a mathematically sophisticated (although not complicated) way to extract meaningful information from the large quantity of data in the human genome.

Broader Impact goals were also successfully accomplished. The PI gave many talks and mini-courses in the USA and internationally to disseminate the work. Outreach goals were fulfilled through the PI’s work with the Ohio State Young Scholars Program. YSP is a state-wide program for gifted high school students from low income households and underrepresented groups. In Summer 2013, the PI was mathematics director for a week long residential mathematics-themed program for YSP 10th graders.
